issue.title: fixes graphql query in the readme
fixes graphql query in the readme
fixes graphql query in the readme
Create database / database schema
issue.body:
This is a crucial part of the app, and needs some time to think about design of the schema. Ideally, we want something that can be modified by whomever decides to adopt the project after this. We should come up with a minimum requirements list for what we will be collecting from the form.

Ideally, I would like to have a time-series or versioning capable database, so that if the administrators decide to change the schema (form questions), we can adjust for that on the server side. What other collections/tables could we have besides form data?

Suggestions:

Users (for logging in and giving permissions) ?
Locations (could be sorted by districts, addresses or geolocation - depending on the granularity we want)
Persons (the homeless whom are being assessed)
Assessments (attached to Persons) *\* I think keeping different versions of assessments that are attached to Persons can be good for keeping a time-series or versioned system to easily query for progress / tracking.
Using this schema can most definitely fit a RDBMS like PostgresQL or a graphDB like ArangoDB.

issue.title: DaDataDudes fork merge into HACC2016 master
Simple GraphQL implementation
issue.body:
Since we're going to be using graphQL, and express is already setup due to Manny's YARS, we can use apolloServer to create an easy implementation of graphQL. We're not performing a whole lot of requests, but we should worry about the schema first before designing any of the GraphQL resolvers, connectors or schemas.

Note: Apollo has come out with a accounts package, similar to Meteor's accounts, which could be an easy drop-in implementation for giving only permitted users access to the DB.

issue.title: Simple GraphQL implementation
issue.body:
Since we're going to be using graphQL, and express is already setup due to Manny's YARS, we can use apolloServer to create an easy implementation of graphQL. We're not performing a whole lot of requests, but we should worry about the schema first before designing any of the GraphQL resolvers, connectors or schemas.

Note: Apollo has come out with a accounts package, similar to Meteor's accounts, which could be an easy drop-in implementation for giving only permitted users access to the DB.
